newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Swedish minister sees sceptical public view on EMU.
newsitem.headline: Swedish minister sees sceptical public view on EMU.

text.p: Swedish Foreign Minister Lena Hjelm-Wallen said on Friday a negative public opinion rather than economic issues created problems for the country when it came to economic and monetary union.

Hjelm-Wallen, participating in a meeting of European Union leaders, reiterated that the leadership of the ruling Social Democratic party would announce its position soon on whether Sweden should join EMU and that the final decision would be taken by parliament in the autumn.
"For us it is not so much economical issues that have created problems. We fulfil the Maastricht criteria, so that is not the problem for us," she told Reuters Financial Television.
"It is much more the (public) opinion, the Swedish opinion that (is) rather reluctant about going further into very close cooperation within the EU," she said.
This "negative opinion" seemed "very sceptical" about monetary union. "That is the biggest problem for us."

Although opinion polls have shown people turning slightly more in favour of EMU, a survey earlier this month showed only 26 percent supported 1999 membership, while 24 percent wanted to join later and 35 percent were against a link. The rest were undecided.
